Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Single Molecule Studies to Dissect the Mechanochemistry of Cytoplasmic Dynein

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific Merit:
Cytoplasmic dynein is a dimeric motor protein responsible for nearly all minus-end directed transport along microtubules in eukaryotic cells. Dynein forms a large dimeric complex and it differs significantly from kinesin motor protein in origin, structure, mechanochemistry and regulation. In comparison with kinesin, whose structure and mechanism are increasingly well understood, we know relatively little about dynein mechanism. The major barriers to studying dynein's motility were the lack of a recombinant expression system and a paucity of tools for observing the movement and conformational states of single motors with sufficient spatial and temporal resolution. The goal of this project is to elucidate the fundamental mechanism of cytoplasmic dynein motility by using state-of-the-art single molecule methods in vitro. Three outstanding questions will be addressed about dynein motility: 1) How is movement of the two motor domains coordinated to maintain high processivity 2) How does ATP hydrolysis in the ring lead to unidirectional motion and which AAA sites are responsible for dynein motility 3) What is the structural basis for dynein's minus-end directionality? Dissecting the mechanism of dynein motility will significantly advance understanding of the way dynein functions in diverse cellular processes.

Broader Impacts:
This project will also include the following educational and outreach components: 1) Establish an educational outreach program for high school students from underrepresented areas of Oakland, CA. 2) Organize summer research opportunities and science fairs in local public schools to attract young generations to science. 3) Develop a new multidisciplinary graduate level course in biophysical imaging methods. 4) Develop a new curriculum with designated emphasis in Biophysics for Physics majors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eukaryotic cells use molecular motors to generate forces and transport cargos along cytoskeletal tracks. On a microtubule filament network, kinesin motors drag cargos towards the plus-end of microtubules, whereas dyneins perform most of the minus-end directed transport. A comprehensive mechanistic understanding of major cellular events, such as mitosis and cell polarization, requires a detailed understanding of both classes of motors.

Dynein is currently the focus of much of the motor biophysics research as the mechanism of its movement is not well understood in comparison to kinesin. Biochemical and structural studies shed light on the structure and conformations of monomeric dynein constructs. However, it was not clear how key structural elements and biochemical states are synchronized to facilitate dynein motility and force generation along microtubules. In the past award period, we used advanced microscopic methods to study the action of single yeast dynein motors in real time. These studies presented a robust mechanistic picture of its stepping, processivity, force generation and catalytic cycle. Briefly, unlike kinesin and myosin, a dynein dimer moves without coordination between the monomers and follows a helical trajectory around microtubules. Both monomers contribute to force generation of a dynein dimer. We identified a unique ATPase site in dynein’s motor domain that repurposes dynein for cargo transportation and microtubule anchoring functions in the cell. In order to understand the mechanism of dynein’s directionality, we engineered a plus-end-directed dynein by changing the length and angle of its stalk which connects the catalytic domain to a microtubule. These modifications act by altering the direction dynein’s linker swings upon nucleotide hydrolysis in the catalytic domain, not by reversing the asymmetric unbinding of the motor from microtubule.

Unlike a well-studied dynein from yeast that walks on its own, mammalian dynein remains in an autoinhibited state and activation of its motility requires formation of a large complex with its cofactor dynactin and a cargo binding adaptor, such as BicD2 and BicDR1.  We recently showed that the dynein-dynactin-BicD2 (DDB) complex produces high (4.5 pN) forces than dynein only, and effectively competes against 6 pN forces generated by plus-end directed kinesin motors during cargo transport.  We also discovered that BicDR1 primarily recruits two dyneins to dynactin. Recruitment of second dynein results in faster motility and production of twice as high forces in comparison to complexes with single dynein. Our studies on engineered complexes revealed that recruitment of second dynein results in faster motility by increasing the dynein ATPase activity and stepping rate, not by altering the direction and size of the steps taken by dynein. Additionally, complexes formed with two dyneins more efficiently compete against kinesin in a bidirectional transport than complexes with single dynein. These results provide a mechanistic basis for how different cargo adaptors modulate dynein’s mechanical properties in order to perform a wide range of cellular functions.
